page.title: 02Cider Orchards
page.content: Many farms in the area have cider orchards. Two of the farms in the area produce their own cider. At Northwood Farm, where Youngs and Mills apples are grown from saplings, they use a traditional wooden press with stone supports. A cheese is made with eight alternate layers of straw and pulp. They put the cheese into the middle of the press which is five feet square and start pressing it. This usually takes four hours. The cider comes out through the bottom and into a trough and finally goes into some barrels or vats. They produce an average of twenty barrels of scrumpy per year. Each barrel holds approximately 120 gallons. At Woodlands House cider is made with a hydraulic press. Some perry pear trees are also grown, the fruit being used to make Babycham.
